video:video.video:title: Intro
video:video.video:description: Introduction to the Atlas of Bacterial & Archaeal Cell Structure, a free multimedia microbiology textbook showcasing real images of bacteria and archaea

video:video.video:title: Light Microscopy
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to light microscopy and how it’s used to image archaea and bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus

video:video.video:title: Fluorescence Light Microscopy
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to fluorescence light microscopy and how it’s used to image components of archaea and bacteria like Escherichia coli flagella

video:video.video:title: Scanning Electron Microscopy
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to electron microscopy and how SEM is used to image the surfaces of archaea and bacteria like Shewanella oneidensis

video:video.video:title: Transmission Electron Microscopy
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to negative-stain TEM and how it’s used to see projection images through archaea and bacteria like Shewanella oneidensis

video:video.video:title: Cryogenic Electron Microscopy
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to cryo-EM and how it’s used to make high-resolution projection images through archaea and bacteria like Caulobacter crescentus

video:video.video:title: Cryogenic Electron Tomography
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to cryo-ET and how it can image archaea and bacteria like Caulobacter crescentus at high resolution in 3D

video:video.video:title: Sub-Tomogram Averaging
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to cryo-ET subtomogram averaging and how it can boost the resolution of bacterial structures like Campylobacter jejuni flagella

video:video.video:title: Single Particle Reconstruction
video:video.video:description: An introduction to cryo-EM single particle reconstruction and how it can reveal structures like the MS-ring of the Salmonella typhimurium flagellar motor

video:video.video:title: X-Ray Crystallography
video:video.video:description: A simple introduction to X-ray crystallography and how it’s used to solve high-resolution structures of proteins like those in the Helicobacter pylori flagellum

video:video.video:title: Putting It All Together
video:video.video:description: How biology techniques, including CLEM and cryo-ET mutant analysis, can combine to create maps of archaea and bacteria like Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus

video:video.video:title: Membrane
video:video.video:description: A phospholipid membrane encloses the contents of all cells, including monoderm Mycoplasma genitalium bacteria, and lets ATP synthase generate energy.

video:video.video:title: Cell Wall
video:video.video:description: A rigid peptidoglycan cell wall supports bacteria like Listeria monocytogenes. Some archaea like Methanobacterium formicicum use a related structure.

video:video.video:title: Outer Membrane
video:video.video:description: Diderm bacteria like Hydrogenovibrio crunogenus have a thin cell wall and a second, outer membrane enclosing a periplasmic space.

video:video.video:title: Vesicles
video:video.video:description: Vesicles bud from membranes of bacteria like Myxococcus xanthus and Borrelia burgdorferi and archaea like Halomicrobium mukohataei.

video:video.video:title: Classification Exceptions
video:video.video:description: Not all bacteria can be classified as Gram-positive or Gram-negative. Mycobacterium marinum have a unique outer membrane and a multi-layered cell wall

video:video.video:title: Surface Layer
video:video.video:description: An external surface layer of protein protects some bacteria like Caulobacter crescentus and Delftia acidovorans. S-layer around vesicles forms nanopods.

video:video.video:title: Surface Layer Variety
video:video.video:description: Protein surface layers look very different on various diderm and monoderm bacteria and archaea, like Sulfolobus solfataricus, N. maritimus or M. formicica.

video:video.video:title: Sheath
video:video.video:description: Methanospirillum hungatei archaea make an external protein sheath that’s highly resistant to pressure. Cells can form long chains with connected sheaths.

video:video.video:title: DNA
video:video.video:description: The DNA in the genomes of bacteria and archaea, like Haloarcula argentinensis, is very thin (~2 nm wide), but can be seen when a cell lyses.

video:video.video:title: Nucleoid
video:video.video:description: Archaea and bacteria, like Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus, contain huge amounts of DNA, which is packed into a concentrated region called the nucleoid.

video:video.video:title: Coccoid
video:video.video:description: Coccoid bacterial cells like Simkania negevensis are spherical and have maximal volume relative to surface area.

video:video.video:title: Rod
video:video.video:description: Most rod-shaped bacteria like Cupriavidus necator use the actin homolog MreB to dictate the shape of their peptidoglycan cell wall.

video:video.video:title: Length
video:video.video:description: Rod-shaped archaeal and bacterial cells like Hylemonella gracilis can grow longer without significantly changing their ratio of surface area to volume.

video:video.video:title: Vibrioid
video:video.video:description: Vibrioid cells of Caulobacter crescentus bacteria use cytoskeletal filaments of Crescentin and CTP synthase to make their curved shape.

video:video.video:title: Helical
video:video.video:description: Helical or wavy bacterial cells like Campylobacter jejuni and Borrelia burgdorferi use their corkscrew shape to burrow into host tissue.

video:video.video:title: Prosthecate
video:video.video:description: Bactofilin and bacterial microtubules are part of the cytoskeleton that lets bacteria like star-shaped Verrucomicrobium spinosum extend prosthecae.

video:video.video:title: Square
video:video.video:description: Gas vesicles help bacteria and archaea like Halobacterium salinarum and thin, square-shaped Haloquadratum walsbyi float.

video:video.video:title: Stalk Bands
video:video.video:description: Stalk bands allow Caulobacter crescentus to use long appendages to take up more nutrients without overly slowing diffusion

video:video.video:title: Nanowires
video:video.video:description: Nanowires allow bacteria like Shewanella oneidensis to grow anaerobically by using an insoluble mineral for respiration

video:video.video:title: Intracytoplasmic Membrane
video:video.video:description: Stacks of intracytoplasmic membrane expand the capacity of photosynthetic bacteria like Rhodopseudomonas palustris or Methyloprofundus sedimenti

video:video.video:title: Enzyme Filaments
video:video.video:description: Polymerization can regulate enzyme activity, and provide cytoskeletal filaments, for bacteria like Clostridium thermocellum

video:video.video:title: Microcompartments
video:video.video:description: Protein-shelled microcompartments serve as metabolic factories for bacteria like Acetonema longum

video:video.video:title: Carboxysomes
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Thiomonas intermedia, Halothiobacillus neapolitanus and Hydrogenovibrio crunogenus use RuBisCO-packed carboxysomes to fix carbon

video:video.video:title: Bacterial Storage Granules
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Cupriavidus necator and Lysobacter antibioticus stockpile nutrients like phosphate or carbon in storage granules

video:video.video:title: Storage Granule Variety
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Agrobacterium tumefaciens or Halothiobacillus neapolitanus use various storage granules, which also interact with carboxysomes

video:video.video:title: Archaeal Storage Granules
video:video.video:description: Archaea like Halorubrum litoreum, Haloferax gibbonssii or Halohasta litchfieldiae use storage granules to stockpile nutrients

video:video.video:title: Copy Number
video:video.video:description: Archaea and bacteria like Thiomonas intermedia have dedicated mechanisms to sort low copy-number components for division

video:video.video:title: Fission
video:video.video:description: Caulobacter crescentus bacteria use a PopZ hub to tether the chromosome to one end of the asymmetric cell for division

video:video.video:title: Budding
video:video.video:description: Budding bacteria like Hyphomonas neptunium pass one copy of their chromosomes through a narrow stalk in preparation for division

video:video.video:title: Monoderm Septum
video:video.video:description: In cytokinesis, bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus build a septum of cell wall to divide into two daughter cells

video:video.video:title: Monoderm Cytokinesis
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Tetrasphaera remsis can divide into two or four daughter cells, by building one or two septa simultaneously

video:video.video:title: Diderm Cytokinesis
video:video.video:description: In cytokinesis, diderm bacteria like Idiomarina loihiensis and Sphingopyxis alaskensis constrict their inner membranes and cells walls to divide

video:video.video:title: Outer Membrane Constriction
video:video.video:description: During cytokinesis, the outer membrane of diderm bacteria like Caulobacter crescentus constricts with, or after, the cell wall, depending on the species

video:video.video:title: Asymmetric Division
video:video.video:description: Some bacteria like Agrobacterium tumefaciens reproduce by budding, with division producing two cells of unequal size

video:video.video:title: Asynchronous Constriction
video:video.video:description: Archaea and bacteria like Cupriavidus necator use cytoskeletal filaments of FtsZ to constrict their cell envelope during cytokinesis

video:video.video:title: FtsZ
video:video.video:description: Archaea and bacteria like Caulobacter crescentus use cytoskeletal filaments of FtsZ to constrict their cell envelope during cytokinesis

video:video.video:title: Archaeal Cytokinesis
video:video.video:description: Some archaea of the Crenarchaeota phylum like Sulfolobus acidocaldarius use a belt of Cdv cytoskeletal filaments to constrict the cell in cytokinesis

video:video.video:title: Cdv
video:video.video:description: Some archaea of the Crenarchaeota phylum like Sulfolobus acidocaldarius use a belt of Cdv cytoskeletal filaments that cinch down the cell to divide

video:video.video:title: Flagellum
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Campylobacter jejuni use a long helical propeller called a flagellum to swim through their liquid environment

video:video.video:title: Flagellar Motor
video:video.video:description: The long propeller-like flagellum of bacteria like Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus is spun by a motor at its base embedded in the cell envelope

video:video.video:title: Flagellar Assembly
video:video.video:description: The flagellum of bacteria like Hylemonella gracilis or Pseudomonas aeruginosa is assembled by a type III secretion system at its base

video:video.video:title: Flagella Patterns
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Campylobacter jejuni have bipolar flagella, one at each end of the cell. Lophotrichous species like Helicobacter pylori have a tuft of flagella

video:video.video:title: Peritrichous Flagella
video:video.video:description: Peritrichous bacteria like Pseudomonas flexibilis and Proteus mirabilis swim using flagella distributed around the cell

video:video.video:title: Sheathed Flagella
video:video.video:description: Some pathogenic bacteria like Helicobacter pylori encase their flagella in a sheath of outer membrane

video:video.video:title: Periplasmic Flagella
video:video.video:description: Spirochete bacteria like Borrelia burgdorferi and Treponema primitia burrow with periplasmic flagella built between the cell wall and outer membrane

video:video.video:title: Archaellum
video:video.video:description: Archaea like Methanoregula formicica use long helical propellers called archaealla to swim. They are assembled and spun by a type II secretion system

video:video.video:title: Archaella Patterns
video:video.video:description: Some lophotrichous archaea like Thermococcus kodakaraensis, but not Halobacterium salinarum, anchor their archaella to a cytoplasmic cone

video:video.video:title: Type IV Pilus
video:video.video:description: Some bacteria like Myxococcus xanthus extend, attach, and retract type IV pili for twitching motility across surfaces

video:video.video:title: Type IX Secretion System
video:video.video:description: Flavobacterium johnsoniae bacteria use machinery including a type IX secretion system, a periplasmic track, and surface adhesins to glide across surfaces

video:video.video:title: Terminal Organelle
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Mycoplasma pneumoniae use an internal terminal organelle and external adhesin proteins to glide across surfaces

video:video.video:title: Chemotaxis
video:video.video:description: Archaea and bacteria like Shewanella oneidensis use chemosensory arrays to sense chemicals in the environment and direct motility through chemotaxis

video:video.video:title: Chemosensory Arrays
video:video.video:description: The hexagonal lattice of chemosensory arrays in archaea and bacteria like Salmonella typhimurium amplifies signal, making them highly sensitive

video:video.video:title: Chemosensory Array Conservation
video:video.video:description: Chemosensory arrays have the same architecture in archaea like Methanospirillum hungatei as in bacteria: a tightly-packed hexagonal lattice of receptors

video:video.video:title: Chemoreceptor Variety
video:video.video:description: Different chemoreceptors assemble into separate arrays based on length in bacteria like Vibrio cholerae and Azospirillum brasilense

video:video.video:title: Cytoplasmic Chemosensory Arrays
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Vibrio cholerae and archaea like Methanoregula formicica have cytoplasmic chemosensory arrays that are not anchored to the membrane

video:video.video:title: Magnetotaxis
video:video.video:description: Iron-filled membrane pockets called magnetosomes enable magnetotactic bacteria like Magnetospirillum magneticum to orient in a magnetic field

video:video.video:title: Stationary Phase
video:video.video:description: Archaea and bacteria like Caulobacter crescentus enter a non-growing stationary phase to try to survive adverse conditions

video:video.video:title: Genome Protection
video:video.video:description: In stationary phase, bacteria like Helicobacter pylori protect their genome with RecA, which forms nucleoprotein complexes and repairs DNA damage

video:video.video:title: Archaeal Stationary Phase
video:video.video:description: In stationary phase, archaea like Thermococcus kodakaraensis protect their DNA with RadA, which forms nucleoprotein filaments and repairs damage

video:video.video:title: Differentiation
video:video.video:description: Caulobacter crescentus bacteria have a dimorphic lifecycle, dividing asymmetrically into a surface-attached stalked cell and a motile swarmer cell

video:video.video:title: Monoderm Sporulation
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Bacillus subtilis can make specialized dormant cells called spores that are highly resistant to acid, heat and dehydration

video:video.video:title: Monoderm Spore Engulfment
video:video.video:description: Endospore-forming bacteria like Bacillus subtilis develop their spores internally, then lyse to release them once they are mature

video:video.video:title: Monoderm Spores
video:video.video:description: Spores of bacteria like Bacillus subtilis are encased in two membranes, a thick cortex, and a multilayered protein coat to protect from harsh conditions

video:video.video:title: Monoderm Germination
video:video.video:description: Spores of monoderm bacteria like Bacillus subtilis germinate by shedding their protein coat and outer membrane as well as the outer cortex

video:video.video:title: Diderm Sporulation
video:video.video:description: Diderm bacteria like Acetonema longum make spores through a specialized division process that starts with formation of a sporulation septum

video:video.video:title: Diderm Spore Engulfment
video:video.video:description: Diderm endospore-forming bacteria like Acetonema longum engulf their spores in two membranes, both of which come from the cell’s inner membrane

video:video.video:title: Diderm Germination
video:video.video:description: Spores of diderm bacteria like Acetonema longum germinate by shedding their protein coat and remodeling their cortex into a thin cell wall

video:video.video:title: Biofilm
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Agrobacterium tumefaciens attach to other cells in a biofilm with pili, holdfast, or unipolar polysaccharide, and secrete cellulose for the matrix

video:video.video:title: Biofilm Matrix
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Gluconacetobacter hansenii secrete cellulose that forms bundles that contribute to the extracellular matrix of their biofilms

video:video.video:title: Type II and Type IV Secretion
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Legionella pneumophila and Helicobacter pylori use type II and type IV secretion systems to pump out effector proteins for infection

video:video.video:title: Type III Secretion
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Pseudomonas aeruginosa use type III secretion system injectisomes to pump effector proteins into other cells

video:video.video:title: Type V Secretion
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Escherichia coli use type V secretion systems to inhibit neighboring cell’s growth through contact-dependent inhibition

video:video.video:title: Type VI Secretion
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Myxococcus xanthus use contractile weapons called type VI secretion systems to shoot toxins into neighboring cells

video:video.video:title: Contractile Weapons
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Vibrio cholerae, Amoebophilus asiaticus and Pseuodalteromonas luteoviolacea use various contractile weapons related to bacteriophage tails

video:video.video:title: Type IX Secretion
video:video.video:description: Porphyromonas gingivalis bacteria use a type IX secretion system to cover themselves in gingipains, which cause the host tissue damage of periodontitis

video:video.video:title: Predation
video:video.video:description: Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus bacteria are predators of other diderm bacteria like Vibrio cholerae. They latch onto their prey with type IV pili

video:video.video:title: Predator Entry
video:video.video:description: Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus breach the outer membrane and invade the periplasm of their prey, other diderm bacteria like Escherichia coli

video:video.video:title: Predator Replication
video:video.video:description: Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus prey on other diderm bacteria like Vibrio cholerae. They digest the contents of the prey cytoplasm to fuel growth and division

video:video.video:title: Phage
video:video.video:description: Viruses like myophage infect bacterial cells like Shewanella oneidensis. They recognize and dock onto cells using their tail fibers

video:video.video:title: Contractile Tails
video:video.video:description: Viruses like myophage use their contractile tails to inject their genomes into bacteria like Bacteroidetes. Not all phage have contractile tails

video:video.video:title: Noncontractile Tails
video:video.video:description: Viruses like siphophage use long, non-contractile tails to deliver their genomes into bacteria like Shewanella oneidensis

video:video.video:title: Structural Variation
video:video.video:description: Podophage use short tails that extend after docking to deliver their genomes into bacteria like Vibrio cholerae. Phage capsids have a variety of shapes

video:video.video:title: Targeting
video:video.video:description: Viruses like MS2 leviphage target the competence pili of bacteria like Escherichia coli, injecting their genomes into the DNA-conducting channel

video:video.video:title: Head Fibers
video:video.video:description: Viruses like φCb13 siphophage wrap their head fibers around the flagella of Caulobacter crescentus. Flagellar rotation draws them down to their receptors

video:video.video:title: Replication
video:video.video:description: Once they infect bacteria like Vibrio cholerae, phage use their host’s machinery to replicate, producing many copies that may lyse the cell to escape

video:video.video:title: Virus-Associated Pyramids
video:video.video:description: Sulfolobus Turreted Icosahedral Virus makes a pyramid in the membrane of infected archaea like Sulfolobus solfataricus to release replicated copies

video:video.video:title: Pyramid Release
video:video.video:description: Virus-associated pyramids open the membrane of Sulfolobus solfataricus archaea to release Sulfolobus Turreted Icosahedral Virus

video:video.video:title: Cellular Defense
video:video.video:description: Bacteria like Shewanella oneidensis may use outer membrane vesicles as decoys to prevent infection by viruses like myophage

video:video.video:title: Keep Looking
video:video.video:description: Conclusion of the Atlas of Bacterial & Archaeal Cell Structure, reminding us that our knowledge of microbiology is still a work in progress
